bibl.title: Letter from T.H. Dougherty, Jr., to Mabel H. Lazear, December 14, 1935

div1.p: The Franklin Institute requests permission to broadcast a drama based on the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from T.H. Dougherty, Jr., to Mabel H. Lazear, December 14, 1935
div1.opener:
THE FRANKLIN INSTITUTE
OF THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA
PHILADELPHIA : : : PENNA.
December 14, 1935
OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR
Mrs. Jesse W. Lazear
6 Oakvale Avenue
Berkeley, Calif.
Dear Mrs. Lazear:
div1.p:
The Franklin Institute, now over one
hundred and fourteen years old, is endeavoring to
arrouse a little more interest on the part of the
public, in the Institute's displays of various
scientific achievements and in the Institute's
popular lectures on subjects concerned with Medicine,
Chemistry, Physics and so on.

One method which we wish to adopt is to
dramatise for the radio, vital and heroic incidents
taken from the lives of well known men of science.

There has been written by Amory Hare, a very
beautiful and stirring drama of the very important part
played by Dr. Lazear in the Walter Read Yellow Fever
Commission sent by the government to Cuba 35 years ago.

May I ask that we be allowed to send a
copy of this drama to you in hopes that you will give
your consent to its being made public in the interests
of The Franklin Institute?
div1.closer: Yours very truly, T. H. Dougherty, Jr. THDjr:C
